newsitem.title: FRANCE: Airbus posts 1996 sales of $8.8 billion.
newsitem.headline: Airbus posts 1996 sales of $8.8 billion.

text.p: European aircraft maker Airbus Industrie said Monday its revenues fell to $8.8 billion last year from $9.6 billion in 1995, based on deliveries of 126 aircraft in 1996.

Although Airbus delivered more planes last year than the 124 planes in 1995, the lower sales figure in 1996 was due to fewer deliveries of the higher value wide-body aircraft, a spokesman for the aircraft grouping said.
Airbus is a consortium of France's Aerospatiale, Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG, British Aerospace and Spain's CASA.
Airbus said in a statement its net increase in orders for 1996 stood at 301 planes, based on 326 firm orders from 31 customers valued at $23.6 billion, and 25 cancellations of previous orders.
But once memoranda of understanding and letters of intent are taken into account, Airbus had 1996 commitments for 498 planes, worth $34.4 billion, excluding options.
It has previously only announced firm orders based on signed sales contracts and deposits received but said it had adopted its competitors' practice of announcing the total number of commitments.

That looser definition allowed Airbus, locked in a dogfight with archrival Boeing Co. to secure a half share of the world market, to say it had a 42 percent share for 1996 sales of aircraft seating more than 100 passengers.

In the 125-350 seater product segment where Airbus competes directly with Boeing, Airbus said it had a 57 percent market share in 1996. Airbus does not field a competitor to Boeing's 777 giant twinjet or the 777 jumbo, which gives the U.S. firm a monopoly in the large capacity area.
